Yes, there are personal actions you can take to reduce your exposure to air pollution. Some of them include:

1. Limiting outdoor activities during times of high pollution: Check the air quality index regularly, particularly if you live in an area with high levels of pollution. When the air quality is poor, limit your outdoor activities, particularly during rush hour or near high-traffic areas.

2. Using air filters: Use air filters at home to reduce indoor air pollution. There are various types of air filters available in the market, some of which are portable and can be used when traveling or at work.

3. Reducing energy consumption: Reducing your energy consumption can help reduce pollution levels. Consider using energy-efficient appliances, and turning off lights and electrical appliances when not in use.

4. Using public transportation, cycling or walking: Using these forms of transportation reduces the number of cars on the road, which in turn reduces the levels of air pollution. 

5. Adopting sustainable practices like recycling, conserving water, using energy-efficient homes, and reducing the use of plastics as they all contribute to reducing air pollution. 

Although these measures may seem small, they can make a significant difference in reducing your exposure to air pollution.
